title: P06-1053

sentences.text: The psycholinguistic literature provides evidence for syntactic priming , i.e. , the tendency to repeat structures .
This paper describes a method for incorporating priming into an incremental probabilistic parser .
Three models are compared , which involve priming of rules between sentences , within sentences , and within coordinate structures .
These models simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data , and also yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy .

Entity-three_model_are_compared__which_i.label: Three models are compared, which involve priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures

priming of rules between sentences, within sentences, and within coordinate structures
Entity-three_model_are_compared__which_i.description: The three linguistic models being compared incorporate syntactic priming by applying rule-based priming mechanisms across sentence boundaries, within individual sentences, and within coordinated structures.

Entity-priming_of_rule.label: priming of rules
Entity-priming_of_rule.description: The process or phenomenon where linguistic rules are influenced by previously encountered sentence structures to repeat similar patterns.

Entity-syntactic_priming.description: The phenomenon of influencing one's linguistic behavior by previous exposure to similar grammatical structures.

Entity-rule_between_sentence.label: rules between sentences
Entity-rule_between_sentence.description: Priming mechanisms that influence parsing decisions across sentence boundaries

Entity-the_reading_time_advantage_for_pa.description: The phenomenon where readers process sentences with parallel structures more quickly than those without such structures, as observed in human reading data.

Entity-incremental_probabilistic_parser.description: A computational model that uses probability theory to parse text incrementally, processing input one step at a time.

Entity-reading_time_advantage.label: reading time advantage
Entity-reading_time_advantage.description: The phenomenon of faster reading times for parallel structures found in human data, as simulated by three models compared in this paper.

Entity-the_tendency_to_repeat_structure.description: A phenomenon where individuals have a propensity to reuse similar grammatical patterns or sentence structures in their language production.

Entity-within_sentence.description: A collection or set of rules that operate within a specific linguistic structure

summary: The psycholinguistic literature provides evidence for syntactic priming , i.e. , the tendency to repeat structures . This paper describes a method for incorporating priming into an incremental probabilistic parser . Three models are compared , which involve priming of rules between sentences , within sentences , and within coordinate structures . These models simulate the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data , and also yield a small increase in overall parsing accuracy .

Predicate-provides_evidence_for.label: provides evidence for
Predicate-provides_evidence_for.description: The predicate 'provides evidence for' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., research findings, data, or studies) offers support or justification for the object (e.g., a hypothesis, theory, or concept). This connection suggests that the information provided by the subject serves as grounds or backing for the object's validity, relevance, or accuracy.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' connects the subject to a description or characterization of an object. It indicates that the subject provides information about the nature, characteristics, or essence of the object.

Predicate-incorporates.label: incorporates
Predicate-incorporates.description: The predicate 'incorporates' indicates that a subject (typically a concept or method) integrates or combines an object (also typically a concept or method), often resulting in a new entity, process, or understanding.

Predicate-involve.label: involve
Predicate-involve.description: The predicate 'involve' indicates a relationship where the subject is part of or has an impact on the object. It suggests that the subject plays a role, contributes to, or participates in the process or phenomenon described by the object.

Predicate-simulate.label: simulate
Predicate-simulate.description: To simulate means to mimic or reproduce an aspect of reality, often in a controlled environment. In this context, it implies that the subject (in this case, 'These models') creates a representation or imitation of the object (the reading time advantage for parallel structures found in human data), which can be used for analysis, testing, or comparison purposes.

Predicate-yield.label: yield
Predicate-yield.description: The predicate 'yield' indicates the production or result of an action, process, or effort. It connects the subject to the object by describing what emerges or arises from a particular activity, often implying a sense of outcome or consequence.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject (a concept or category) encompasses or includes the object (also a concept or category), suggesting a hierarchical relationship between them, where the subject represents a more general or overarching entity and the object is a specific instance or subcategory.
